coming so I'm not not quite talking about crowdsourcing today but really
what I want to share with you today is how I've worked to align my work with my
values and my hopes for the world okay but my hope for this talk is not so much
that you walk out of here with my values but instead that you're inspired to think a bit more about your own values
how how to realize them out in the world and I think that'd be really wonderful if that's the outcome of this talk so
with that I'd like to share with you some thoughts on computational ecosystems and what I think they can do for advancing human values at scale so I
want to start by just noting this question that as I started learning more about my work what I realized is that
all these challenges and questions I was interested in essentially came down to
this question how can we create scalable solutions to human problems and advance
desire human values in the absence of a technology that can overcome real-world
constraints okay so as a computer scientist and as a technologist like many of you are this is a really
unfortunate question for me to be asking right but it's just the question that kept coming up okay so let me start by
giving you an example when I first got to Northwestern I began mentoring undergraduate students in research ok
and this photo is taken from spring 2014 I started a program called design technology and research and we started
with just seven students but in about two years I was mentoring over 20
students in 14 independent research projects and very quickly I learned that faculty time doesn't scale okay like you
can't you could kind of stretch it a little bit but not really right I mean there's a fixed number of hours in the day
so the general challenge then is how can a single faculty mentor train 20-plus
students right this is the part about scaling the solution to this problem to cultivate autonomous self-directed
learners right so people who are going to do independent work and build new knowledge for science right these are
the values that I cared about in this project but in the absence of a
technology that scales my time okay and this is the real world constraint you know like I said can't
really stretch it so as we started thinking about this problem we realized that it's actually really hard and the
reason it's really hard is that the best human solution which is awesome it doesn't scale very well okay and the
best human solution we know is called a printer ship or 101 mentoring as you're familiar with and it's a highly effective model for training people to
do complex tasks but as alan collins reminds us and alan collins kind of like the Godfather of cognitive
apprenticeship which is apprenticeship of the mind for skills like research he says the sadly apprenticeship
requires a very small teacher to learn a ratio that's just not realistic in the
large educational systems of modern economies and we might think that like
some other problems there'd be a good machine solution but here it's really not clear that there's a best machine
solution in sight so software can be used to provide helpful prompts to guys student thinking but no AI technology
can replace the mentor in the foreseeable future right and one of the ways to think about that is that to have
an AI to do this you really want a model of how to solve complex ill structure problems as you would come commonly see
in design and in research and you will want to have models of instruction for teaching people how to do that right and
we have neither of those two things so now if you think about what options we
have given this is kind of a state of affairs we could wait for a technological silver bullet right but it
could take quite a while or it might never come you could imagine instead compromising in a variety of way so
instead of scaling undergraduate research you could try to scale lecture right you could do MOOCs you could do
those kinds of things you could train a small set of uni students right as we typically do with PhD students or you
could give undergrads route work you just say okay here's a project you know here's some stuff to do and that's still good right because you're getting
undergrad to involved in research yet none of these options really provide the same learning benefits and scale as the
values that I wanted to scale so over the last five years this general
question has led us to the design of what I call computational ecosystems and what computational ecosystems are is
that their systems that inner weave community process social structures and
intelligence systems to unite people and machines to overcome these larger challenges okay so as you can see from
this figure computational ecosystems incorporate many different components and the goal here is not just to concern
us with the design of components but instead with the design of the entire system and this focus on a systems
approach to design echos calls from people like Atul Gawande from the Harvard Medical School who
argues that in essence having great components is not enough okay so here Atul says we've been obsessed in
medicine with components we want the best drugs the best technologies the best specialists but we don't think too
much about how it all comes together it's a terrible design strategy actually and Atul goes on to say that making
systems work is the great task of our generation of physicians and scientists I would go further to say that making
systems work whether it's a healthcare education climate change and making a pathway out of poverty is the great task
of our generation as a whole we also see this call for system level thinking in
artificial intelligence so here's Erik Horvitz who's the director of Microsoft Research and he says I'm pretty sure
that the next leaps in AI will come from integrative systems rather than wedges right so wedges being components or
wedges of intelligence he argues that we need to focus on building a system where
the whole is greater than the parts and closer to home in HCI there's been
similar calls for a need for system level thinking so one such call comes from George furnace who in this
wonderful paper called future design mindful of the morass which all the students should read if you're
interested in designing systems and he says it's likely that our designs will be more successful if we became more
mindful of the bigger picture the mosaic of responsive adaptive systems right now
what he's referring to is that if we're designing applications we need to think about how those applications fit into the larger systems that in which that
application operates okay now I think would be really wise for all of us the heat George's words
but as it turns out we need to do more than just be mindful of the larger system we actually need to design the
entire system for solving some of the problems that I'm interested in so to
design this entire system we take a socio-technical approach as you may already be familiar with but we extend
it in variety of ways to account for the added complexity of having to design the whole system okay
so for example when designing a socio-technical system we typically do consider the context of the larger system but in practice solutions are
often created component by component or layer by layer okay so let me give you some examples of that so for example we
might be thinking about supporting group collaboration and focus on new collaboration technologies for
supporting a group right or we might as many people in the room and myself in the past think about creating
technologies for coordinating crowds okay and this is all great but one of the things we're thinking about with
computational ecosystems as an approach to design is that we're interested in how to bring together multiple
structures of people and interactions to jointly solve a problem that gives us new synergies that can arrive when these
component interactions inform each other to enable new kinds of solutions so as
another example you could consider designing layer by layer okay so we might first come up with a process of working like this is how our group or
organization is going to work and then we might design the social structures for supporting that way of working and
then go on to design tools based on those social structures and the process
of work right and this is actually a very thoughtful approach to designing technologies right because you're considering things that are in place for
example in your organization and especially of those processes as social structures are things that you can't
change but what I was interested in is thinking about are there opportunities to design an entire vertical slice as
one right where there might be new compositions of processes working with the structure of social interactions and
technologies that kind of all work well together and gives you very different designs then if you assume certain
things to be fixed so in essence what I'm saying is that with computational
ecosystems we're interested in designing simultaneously all the components of a
socio technical system as a single integrative solution okay so we're still going to be thinking about
people and technology but we're gonna take a more comprehensive approach where we construct the parts but also how all
the parts interact together both technically and people-wise as well and to do this and to reason about the added
complexity of thinking about the whole system we're gonna adopt two helpful perspectives in our design work so one
of the ideas is computational thinking just as you're already familiar with but we're thinking about computational thinking to decompose and distribute
problem-solving to humans and machines who could best address them across the entire ecosystem and the other idea is
something that I call ecological thinking and the idea there is that we want to create sustainable processes and
interactions that support both the ecosystem members but furthermore supports proper ecosystem function okay
so as I go through my talk and present some examples of ecosystems you're gonna see ideas from this kind of
computational thinking ecological thinking throughout the examples so for
the rest of the talk I'm gonna present two examples of computational ecosystems one for community-based planning and

and now I'll just end with some thoughts on what technology what the role of

try to come up with a preliminary schedule for for CAI and this is taken in 2012 and what they're doing is
they're trying to construct hundreds of sessions about 200 over a two-day period on paper on the wall okay so that's the
test they were facing and immediately you can see that these organizers face some critical challenges okay so the
first one is that there's about I want to say about 10 organizers that are in the room and what you see is that they
lack information about what it is that the whole community wants right and what it is that the whole community know so
Kai's gotten I think it's probably bigger than this now but even then it was about 500 papers and it's became
pretty hard for any single person or any ten people to really have a good understanding of all the content right
so to even know what papers relate to each other and will make for a good session is something that's very
difficult to do at the small group much less what all the preferences of all the thousands of attendees who are attending
might be and furthermore the organizers lack tools for managing the complexity
of the planning problem and also in resolving conflicts okay so clearly there are some challenges just working
on this with paper as the only tool that they had available but what was even more difficult is when the chairs go
home they put this schedule into a computer and then they go through this super painful and time-consuming process
as they're trying to resolve conflicts where they try to resolve one conflict right by moving a session to an
excuse me to another place but then you have to swap right so another session goes in its place and then you create
another conflict all right so you resolve wine you create wine and what they described it as is a terrible game
of whack-a-mole right where the Mo's are conflicts so it's really unpleasant okay
and to overcome these challenges then we created Kobe which is a computational
ecosystem for a new process that we call community informed planning okay and Kobe's belt on just two simple ideas one
engaged the entire community in the planning process and the second one give organizers tools to manage the
complexity of planning and resolve conflicts right so these ideas are very simple but the real question is how do
you do this right and that's where we're gonna see some interesting ideas in ecosystem thinking so let me start by
talking about engaging the whole community in planning so to do this we created new processes and tools for
involving committee members authors and attendees so we engage committee members to make the initial sessions right after
the PC meeting we ask authors to tell us which papers fit well in a session with their own paper but also what talks they
want to see so we make sure those talks are not kind of opposing the session that they're presenting their paper in
we then help attendees navigate the schedule with a tool called comfor where
we are recommending papers and sessions to people and as people favorite them we're starting to identify what the
popular sessions are going to be um so we could put them in bigger rooms and then we also could identify talks of mutual interest so if a lot of people
want to see this talk and that talk and they're at the same time right you want to move them so that they're not at the
same time okay um so so far this is pretty straightforward right it's a crowdsourcing kind of problem and we're
thinking about kind of designing for each of these groups of people but right off the bat there's actually some
computational challenges we need to think about okay so if we just focus on committee sourcing for a second and
think about the problem of making sessions one of the things that you must account for is thinking about how to
coordinate problem solving given that there are global constraints okay so let me just give you an example is if you
think about a paper write a paper could often fit into many possible sessions right not just one but here's the thing
if you collect a bunch of potential sessions that's not necessarily enough right because the
paper is only going to go to one and once this paper goes into this session oh the other potential sessions that had
those other papers those fall apart right so you have to have to think about the intent dependencies across these
sessions because you have these session making constraints so to resolve this
challenge the first core idea I'm going to present is using this two-phase collaborative planning process that
involves both a large crowd of all the ACS and a smaller group of about ten
aces okay so in phase one we're gonna involve all the ACS to elicit metadata
or possible groupings of papers into sessions okay and then in Phase two a smaller group of ACS
were given all these flexible options that were collected can deliberate and discuss in a small group how to satisfy
the tighter constraints right which are more difficult to do in a crowd so as
you're doing this in real time right you might have 200 people kind of tagging and going in at the same time to manage
this process we have a system cuff frenzy led by Lydia Chilton and what it does is it uses actionable feedback
which are these things on the left to tell people what it is that still needs work right so it's just telling people hey
these are things still need to be tagged these are things that still needs to be put into sessions but what's interesting about the system is that using the same
system by changing the actionable feedback at different phases of problem solving you can make it into a crowd
where system at first where a lot of people are participating and then you're just shifting the feedback you're giving and then it becomes a group or system as
you might traditionally think about and it supports small group working together and deliberating and having these discussions as well alright so so
there's just the example of how you can move from a crowd to a group by designing across so coming back to the
general challenge of engaging the community for authors and attendees we're gonna need ways to give them relevant suggestions right of papers
that might be similar to theirs and then for attendees of things they might want to see and you could you could clearly
treat this as a machine problem right and think about these as isolated questions where here you might do some
TF idea for something like that and then there you might do collaborative filtering right and then you build up a preference profile over time and that's
all very reasonable and you could definitely do that but you could do better than that if you take a ecosystems kind of view on this
okay and the second core idea I'm going to present to you is this idea I call incentive chaining okay and the idea
behind incentive chaining is that we're going to try to engage increasing sets of ecosystem members by using the data
collected in an earlier interaction and seeding it to get further contributions from subsequent interactions and making
that better okay so for example what we do here is that we take the expert categories that are generated through
frenzy by the program committee members and then we couple it with tf-idf to produce a short list of similar papers
for authors so they don't have to scan through hundreds of papers to find what's relevant and in studies what we found is that having this kind of human
expert input with the machine input coupled gives you much better suggestions than if you just do tf-idf
by yourself and then we continue the chain by taking about 10,000 data points
we get from the authors as see data into our collaborative filtering algorithm and what you get then is you basically
skip what's called the Coe start problem right so normally in collaborative filtering you kind of have to like a bunch of stuff before it starts giving you pretty good
recommendations and here you get great recommendations right off the bat because not only are you getting it from
authors right it's actually like a double filter right like you got the committee members making these good groupings and then the authors kind of
refined it even further so we give really good recommendations right off the bat and then now you have more
authors sorry more attendees participating and going in there and liking things that they like because you
know they're just seeing it like oh I like this I like this and we get more data for planning as well so moving on
to step two helping the organizers resolve conflicts with all this data we've collected we should just feed it
all into a computer hidden optimize button and get a schedule out right no
it's a terabyte please don't do that okay and there's many reasons for it I'm
just gonna give you two reasons right now one is that the problem is still actually highly under specified right so we end up collecting about 1020 thousand
data points turns out that's only a small portion of the specification of the planning problem and for the parts that the
Machine doesn't know right it's only gonna optimize what it knows you hit the optimize button and it's easy to get some incoherent

wouldn't be such a big problem except that the organizers don't even know necessarily that these are bad sessions

found is that if you really want students to be self-directed so that they could do independent research
they're gonna need something that's commonly known in psychology and learning sciences as regulation skills
okay and what regulation skills are is given a complex goal or some goal that you have what are all the cognitive
metacognitive motivational and emotional skills you have or you would need to have to reach that goal right and for
research the required regulation skills includes things like planning your work and monitoring your progress and
replanting as needed and then also seeking help to overcome challenges as they come up and students lacking these skills are
confined to route tasks right like they're kind of given something to do you know can't self direct or they could
struggle to make progress where you know they might hit a block and then wait a week until they meet with their faculty mentor before it gets resolved okay and
the thing that um you know for me I just want to point out here beyond the slides is that regulation skills are actually
really hard to learn a lot of students struggle with regulation skills okay I certainly did as a PhD student I you
know I still do to to a large extent but the flip side of that is sorry to all the faculty in the room we do a terrible
job of teaching regulation skills right and often well you find and maybe it's
different here but is that you know doing research could feel a lot like just bang your head against the wall and then like one day you figure it out
right and I know that's not true for everyone but I see enough of it to think that there's got to be a better way that
we could get better results with more students by helping students build these regulation skills more effectively so to
address this challenge we created a computational ecosystem that we call agile research studios that provides a
model for research training within a learning community and in this model all the students regardless of seniority conduct
independent research and receive authentic research practice by which I mean the students will go through a
self-directed project cycle where they set goals themselves they learn they plan their work they make progress they
reflect on what's been learned and then they go through this cycle again so the
core idea here for ARS is that as scales mentor time right or faculty time right
